subtopic: Radiocarbon calibration curves and reservoir effects
main_point: The professor explains Radiocarbon calibration curves and reservoir effects and how to interpret evidence when measurements can be misleading.
detail1: The professor distinguishes context (a process) from taphonomy (a proxy/measurement).
detail2: He suggests testing an asymmetric prediction involving stratigraphy and calibration curve.
attitude: Casual but analytical; he warns against over-trusting a neat correlation.
organization_point: He adds a tangent about a funding detail to show real-world constraints.
connecting_point: The example about controlling for typology shows how bias can flip an apparent pattern.
